No apparatus for catching those glasses that fly off from heated substances—and which make so very material a part of modern chymistry—nor one process of any sort going forward.
bibliographic_reference: Walker, Adam (1787). Ideas suggested on the spot in a Late Excursion through Flanders, Germany, France and Italy.
place: Di Studio - Scuola di Chimica Istituto

name: The School of Philosophy (made famous by a female Professor, who died…
fragment: The School of Philosophy (made famous by a female Professor, who died a few years ago) I was particularly wishful to see—sorry that in this I was also disappointed. Here we found a number of ill-made instruments (mostly on the plan of Gravesand's) nothing new, except a pretty large plate electrical machine. A new air-pump was just trying, with the two cylinders horizontal, and open in the old way, very clumsy, which extracted very slow, yet seemed tolerably staunch. On enquiring after the Observatory, we found it was out of order—so we just inspected some good models of ships, fortifications, &c. and took our leave.
bibliographic_reference: Walker, Adam (1787). Ideas suggested on the spot in a Late Excursion through Flanders, Germany, France and Italy.
place: Di Studio - Scuola di Filosofia Istituto

name: In Bologna there is perhaps the tallest tower, for its thickness, of a…
fragment: In Bologna there is perhaps the tallest tower, for its thickness, of any in the world—it is 327 feet high—and its side on a medium, (for it grows smaller and smaller as one ascends) about 1o feet; it is called the Asinelli Tower, and is said to lean 3 } feet out of its perpendicular— it is of brick, and was built in 1109. Our heads must needs turn round on the top of this tower; –but we were amply re compensed by the view—we saw Milan, Ferrara, the Alps, Appenines, &c. and the town looked like a map beneath our feet.
bibliographic_reference: Walker, Adam (1787). Ideas suggested on the spot in a Late Excursion through Flanders, Germany, France and Italy.

name: Besides the very tall tower, and near it, there stands another, about…
fragment: Besides the very tall tower, and near it, there stands another, about the same thickness, but only 130 feet high, that has either been taken down, or never built higher; for its foundation on one side has given way so much, that it leans upwards of ten or twelve feet out of the perpendicular. One is almost afraid of walking near it—they are both of brick, and one wonders, why the weight does not break the lower bricks.
bibliographic_reference: Walker, Adam (1787). Ideas suggested on the spot in a Late Excursion through Flanders, Germany, France and Italy.

name: Our next visit was to the Opera-house, which is said to be one of the…
fragment: Our next visit was to the Opera-house, which is said to be one of the finest in Italy. It has five heights of galleries, each box bulging a little out of the general round, so as to make the whole have an airy look: its form is exactly like ours, but not so large—the pit is filled with loose benches.
bibliographic_reference: Walker, Adam (1787). Ideas suggested on the spot in a Late Excursion through Flanders, Germany, France and Italy.

name: In the palace of Samperi, there are Colossal figures, in fresco, on th…
fragment: In the palace of Samperi, there are Colossal figures, in fresco, on the ceiling of several rooms, that shew how much those artists were masters of the human figure, in every possible attitude. But Guido's picture of St. Peter and St. Paul struck me more than any picture I have seen, since I saw the martyrdom of St. Peter, by Rubens
bibliographic_reference: Walker, Adam (1787). Ideas suggested on the spot in a Late Excursion through Flanders, Germany, France and Italy.

name: This town is famous for the richness of the soil that lies about it, a…
fragment: This town is famous for the richness of the soil that lies about it, and the magnificence of its convents. It is likewise esteemed the third in Italy for pictures, as having been the school of Lombard painters.
bibliographic_reference: Addison, Joseph (1705). Remarks on Several Parts of Italy, & co. In the Years 1701, 1702, 1703.

name: We passed a whole day very agreeably at Bologna: it is rich in picture…
fragment: We passed a whole day very agreeably at Bologna: it is rich in pictures both of its own and other schools. Fourscore of these pictures had made the journey to Paris—a sure proof of their merit. At the Academia delle Belle Arti is a collection which has its superior perhaps only at Florence
bibliographic_reference: Beste, Henry Digby (1828). Italy as it Is; Or, Narrative of an English Family's Residence for Three Years in that Country.

name: Bologna is a fine old town: most of the streets have arcades, or what…
fragment: Bologna is a fine old town: most of the streets have arcades, or what are improperly called piazzas, on both sides—a shelter in this climate rather from the sun than from the rain, but in all cases a most useful and agree able arrangement, which would be oftener followed, but for the difficulty of reconciling the interest of the proprietors of the houses and that of the public.
bibliographic_reference: Beste, Henry Digby (1828). Italy as it Is; Or, Narrative of an English Family's Residence for Three Years in that Country.

name: In the grand piazza, or square, are seen the admirable statues in bron…
fragment: In the grand piazza, or square, are seen the admirable statues in bronze, by John of Bologna, which adorn the fountain.
bibliographic_reference: Beste, Henry Digby (1828). Italy as it Is; Or, Narrative of an English Family's Residence for Three Years in that Country.

name: The cathedral is under the invocation of St. Petronius, patron of the…
fragment: The cathedral is under the invocation of St. Petronius, patron of the city; he is in great veneration. I have seen money bearing his effigies. It is not uncommon in Italy to stamp current coin with the figures of saints: but, besides St. Petronius, I have met only with those of the Blessed Virgin, Sts. Peter and Paul, St. Andrew, and at Genoa, St. John the Baptist.
bibliographic_reference: Beste, Henry Digby (1828). Italy as it Is; Or, Narrative of an English Family's Residence for Three Years in that Country.

name: The two towers or pillars of Bologna, one of which is so very tall, an…
fragment: The two towers or pillars of Bologna, one of which is so very tall, and the other stands awry, though remarked by every one, are remarkable only from their awkward look. They are of brick, and were they near a malt-kiln, or a smithy, they would not seem out of their places. It is, perhaps, more to be wondered at, that the inclined tower of Bologna does not fall, than that the tower of Pisa yet stands, being of larger bulk, of a circular form, and built of stone, all contributing to greater stability.
bibliographic_reference: Beste, Henry Digby (1828). Italy as it Is; Or, Narrative of an English Family's Residence for Three Years in that Country.

name: Bologna is in the very centre of the peninsula, and on that side of th…
fragment: Bologna is in the very centre of the peninsula, and on that side of the Apennines on which lies its main extent of territory, and its ready communication with foreign nations.
bibliographic_reference: Beste, Henry Digby (1828). Italy as it Is; Or, Narrative of an English Family's Residence for Three Years in that Country.

name: They talk an excessively bad Italian at Bologna:
fragment: They talk an excessively bad Italian at Bologna:
bibliographic_reference: Beste, Henry Digby (1828). Italy as it Is; Or, Narrative of an English Family's Residence for Three Years in that Country.

name: Behind an altar, which stands in the middle of the church, is a very o…
fragment: Behind an altar, which stands in the middle of the church, is a very odd pedestal, above which we see a corinthian capital reversed, then a broken column, and over all a cross, part of which is the wood of the holy cross; and all these, they say, were brought from Jerusalem.
bibliographic_reference: Drummond, Alexander (1754). Travels Through Different Cities of Germany, Italy, Greece and Several Parts of Asia, as the Far as the Banks of the Euphrates, in a Series of Letters.
place: Di Culto - Chiesa di San Giovanni in Monte

name: The church of St. Petronio is gothic, built in an odd taste, which, ho…
fragment: The church of St. Petronio is gothic, built in an odd taste, which, however, is not without dignity. He is patron of the city, and under his statue we read this inscription: Prisca diu non prisca modo quae apparet imago Nos nova Petronij priscaque dona docet. 1708. I should not have wondered to see these lines dared three or four hundred years ago; but, to ﬁnd such gothic conceits of these days, gives a lamentable idea of modern taste. The great altar is extremely well designed, being an antique cupola, supported by four corinthian columns; upon the pavement is the Linea meridiana, a vertice ad tropicum capricorni, the sun darting through a small hole of the roof, when in the meridian, his rays strike the hour upon this graduated line, contrived by Mr. Cassini, and thereby their time is regulated; for their division is not by regular periods, like ours : their ﬁrst hour begins half an hour after sun set, and so they reckon on 'till four and twenty ; and therefore must be continualy altering their clocks and watches.
bibliographic_reference: Drummond, Alexander (1754). Travels Through Different Cities of Germany, Italy, Greece and Several Parts of Asia, as the Far as the Banks of the Euphrates, in a Series of Letters.

name: upon the pavement is the Linea meridiana, a vertice ad tropicum capric…
fragment: upon the pavement is the Linea meridiana, a vertice ad tropicum capricorni, the sun darting through a small hole of the roof, when in the meridian, his rays strike the hour upon this graduated line, contrived by Mr. Cassini, and thereby their time is regulated; for their division is not by regular periods, like ours : their ﬁrst hour begins half an hour after sun set, and so they reckon on 'till four and twenty ; and therefore must be continualy altering their clocks and watches.
bibliographic_reference: Drummond, Alexander (1754). Travels Through Different Cities of Germany, Italy, Greece and Several Parts of Asia, as the Far as the Banks of the Euphrates, in a Series of Letters.

name: there is the picture of an executioner in the act of beheading a faint…
fragment: there is the picture of an executioner in the act of beheading a faint, with a long sword, having a great deal of fury expressed in his countenance. In St. Gregory's church, there is an admirable piece by Lodovico Caracci, representing St. George and St. Margaret, who was relieved by his knightly arm ; together with the angel Gabriel above: and another excellent picture of St. Gregory performing a miracle, by Dionysius Calvert.
bibliographic_reference: Drummond, Alexander (1754). Travels Through Different Cities of Germany, Italy, Greece and Several Parts of Asia, as the Far as the Banks of the Euphrates, in a Series of Letters.

name: In the church of St. Francis, we see St. Anthony raising a person from…
fragment: In the church of St. Francis, we see St. Anthony raising a person from the dead, extremely well painted by Laurentio Pacinelli; and the conversion of St. Paul, ﬁnely performed by Lodovico Caracci. The sculpture of two chappels, on the sides of the great altar, is very well executed; one being of Giallo & verdo antico: the cloisters are likewise beautifully adorned with busts of the monks of the Franciscan order; and, from the ﬂight of the stair-case, is a ſine prospect of two corridores, the one above the other. Here are no fewer than one hundred and ﬁfty fathers, who live like drones upon the industry of their fellow creatures: some of them, however, are men of real worth; and very sensible of the injury which accrues' to mankind from such idle institutions.
bibliographic_reference: Drummond, Alexander (1754). Travels Through Different Cities of Germany, Italy, Greece and Several Parts of Asia, as the Far as the Banks of the Euphrates, in a Series of Letters.
place: Di Culto - Basilica Di San Francesco

name: Santo Salvator is a glorious building, having three noble chapels on e…
fragment: Santo Salvator is a glorious building, having three noble chapels on each side, before you come to the body of the nave, with a cupola over it; the whole is of the composite order, channelled, and the statuary is good.
bibliographic_reference: Drummond, Alexander (1754). Travels Through Different Cities of Germany, Italy, Greece and Several Parts of Asia, as the Far as the Banks of the Euphrates, in a Series of Letters.
place: Di Culto - Chiesa di San Salvatore

name: The Dominican church is very elegant: the lower columns of the vaultin…
fragment: The Dominican church is very elegant: the lower columns of the vaulting being ionic, the high pilasters corinthian, the Ornaments of stucco, and the whole executed in a very good taste. St. Andrew half undressed, for cruciﬁxion, by Rossi is a ﬁne piece; and the chappels that cross the nave are magnificent. Pope Pius V, by Felicio Torelli; and St. Jacinto, by Lodovico Caracci, must attract the eye of every man who knows any thing of A painting. St. Dominick's head and relics are preserved within an altar, but I could not see them, because he who kept the key was absent. The Dome church is really grand, and will be still more so, when the portico is ﬁnished;
bibliographic_reference: Drummond, Alexander (1754). Travels Through Different Cities of Germany, Italy, Greece and Several Parts of Asia, as the Far as the Banks of the Euphrates, in a Series of Letters.

name: the whole is of the composite order, the capitals and modelion-cornish…
fragment: the whole is of the composite order, the capitals and modelion-cornish being very rich; but those by the gate are no more than paintings. On each ﬁde is a row of arched columns, or what are frequently called cloysters, and the complete nave seems to be well proportioned to the-length : the roof is arched and plain ; and one altar is adorned with giallo, verdo antico, and other stones of great value. There is a ﬁne altar erected by the heirs of Gregory V, and supported with giallo cointhian columns; there are four organs in the church, and two in the coir, supported by Tuscan pillars; three altars in architecture, the others in painting; though the deceptions have a good eﬀect: and as rich people die or superstitious zeal increases, real buildings will be reared in room of these appearances.
bibliographic_reference: Drummond, Alexander (1754). Travels Through Different Cities of Germany, Italy, Greece and Several Parts of Asia, as the Far as the Banks of the Euphrates, in a Series of Letters.

name: The church of the Padri Philippini del Oratorio, is one of those that…
fragment: The church of the Padri Philippini del Oratorio, is one of those that (as l have already observed) please me, like a pretty, plain girl, by their neatness and white apparel. All the ornaments are corinthian, gilt, except the great altar, which is coloured, and two others, which are very elegant. Here is a young Jesus declaiming in the temple, and God above, with angels, by Albani; and it is observable of this great master, that there is not one of his pieces (at least I have seen none of them) without infant ﬁgures, either of angels, cupids, or mortals; and in these he was never equalled. Here is likewise a picture of Jesus, and Thomas feeling his wounds, by a fair lady called Teresia Mauratori, performed in a masterly manner.
bibliographic_reference: Drummond, Alexander (1754). Travels Through Different Cities of Germany, Italy, Greece and Several Parts of Asia, as the Far as the Banks of the Euphrates, in a Series of Letters.

name: In St. Margaret’s church, over the altar, is the picture of that femal…
fragment: In St. Margaret’s church, over the altar, is the picture of that female faint, with the virgin above, which is certainly a lovely figure, painted by Macini; there is likewise a very good Magdalen, by one of Guido’s scholars. St. Catharine receiving a young Jesus, by Permigiano, is an excellent piece :
bibliographic_reference: Drummond, Alexander (1754). Travels Through Different Cities of Germany, Italy, Greece and Several Parts of Asia, as the Far as the Banks of the Euphrates, in a Series of Letters.
place: Di Culto - Chiesa e Monastero di Santa Margherita

name: The cieling of St. Paul’s church is ﬁnely painted in fresco; the pilas…
fragment: The cieling of St. Paul’s church is ﬁnely painted in fresco; the pilasters are composite and channelled. A nativity, by Alexander Dorchi, and another by Cavedoni, are good pictures. On the great altar, are the statues of the faint and executioner, by Algardi, which might stand among the antiques. The father, and a dead Jesus, by Crespi ; St. Catharine de Bologna, a dead Jesus, by Marco Antonio Francischini; the church, by him and his scholars, together with an ascension, by Hannibal Caracci, are much to be regarded.
bibliographic_reference: Drummond, Alexander (1754). Travels Through Different Cities of Germany, Italy, Greece and Several Parts of Asia, as the Far as the Banks of the Euphrates, in a Series of Letters.
place: Di Culto - Basilica di San Paolo Maggiore

name: to Fiorenzola is a very steep way, and to Loyan 14 Miles indifferent g…
fragment: to Fiorenzola is a very steep way, and to Loyan 14 Miles indifferent good, through the Mountains, both sides are full of chestnut Trees. From thence to Bolonia are counted 16 Miles, half the way we went through the Mountains, but the rest is very pleasant
bibliographic_reference: Chancel, Alexander D. (1714). A New Journey over Europe.

name: here are several magnificent Churches, the greatest of which is that o…
fragment: here are several magnificent Churches, the greatest of which is that of St. Petronius, in the Pavement of which is represented Cassinian's Meridional Line 220 Foot long, drawn in Copper; it will be one of the finest Churches In Europe, when finish’d.
bibliographic_reference: Chancel, Alexander D. (1714). A New Journey over Europe.

name: This City lies at the foot of the Appennin Hills, which on the South-s…
fragment: This City lies at the foot of the Appennin Hills, which on the South-side are cover'd with Vines, Olive, Fig, and other Fruit trees of all Sorts; on the other Side there are Fields abounding with Corn, Flax, and fine Rows of Mulberry trees, which nourish a Multitude of Silk-worms.
bibliographic_reference: Chancel, Alexander D. (1714). A New Journey over Europe.

name: This City is so large, that it gave a convenient Entertainment to the…
fragment: This City is so large, that it gave a convenient Entertainment to the Emperor Charles the 5th, with all the Princes and Ambassadors that attended him, with the Pope and 15 Cardinals, when the said Emperor was crown'd there in the Year 1529.
bibliographic_reference: Chancel, Alexander D. (1714). A New Journey over Europe.

name: Here are many fine Palaces, private Houses, and a great Number of Towe…
fragment: Here are many fine Palaces, private Houses, and a great Number of Towers, whereof that of Asinelli is as high as any in Europe
bibliographic_reference: Chancel, Alexander D. (1714). A New Journey over Europe.

name: it is the second Town of the ecclesiastical State, and one of the larg…
fragment: it is the second Town of the ecclesiastical State, and one of the largest, best peopled, and finest in Italy
bibliographic_reference: Chancel, Alexander D. (1714). A New Journey over Europe.

name: Scarce any City in Europe could have entertain'd such a Multitude of P…
fragment: Scarce any City in Europe could have entertain'd such a Multitude of Persons of the highest Rank, with their Attendants and Guards.
bibliographic_reference: Chancel, Alexander D. (1714). A New Journey over Europe.

name: Stretching far as the eye can reach, is a chain of distant snow-capped…
fragment: Stretching far as the eye can reach, is a chain of distant snow-capped Alps — the Adriatic, like a streak of light, is visible on the horizon ; while spread out below are the wide and fertile plains, with an occasional gleam from the winding Savenna. On this river stands the ancient city of Bologna, the capital of the most populous and flourishing of the States of the Church
bibliographic_reference: Dunbar, Margaret Juliana (1853). Art and Nature under an Italian Sky.

name: On entering its wide and handsome streets, the first peculiarity the s…
fragment: On entering its wide and handsome streets, the first peculiarity the stranger observes is the covered archway on each side, giving not only character to its streets, but affording a most grateful shade from the heat of the sun, and doubtless also protection from the storms of winter. At the same time one would suppose they must darken the shops and lower parts of the houses very dismally, especially in the old part of the city where the colonnades are low and heavy.
bibliographic_reference: Dunbar, Margaret Juliana (1853). Art and Nature under an Italian Sky.

name: The Bolognese School of Painting is one of the most celebrated, and bo…
fragment: The Bolognese School of Painting is one of the most celebrated, and boasts a constellation of the brightest genius. Passing over its earlier epochs, the period of its greatest glory began with the Caracci, in the sixteenth century, who introduced an entirely new style of painting, and were remarkable for the pious pupils they produced. Of these, the first and greatest was Domenichino, who has been called the second painter in the world — second only to Raphael. Scarcely inferior to him is Guido, who must be seen in Bologna to be thoroughly appreciated ; and Guercino, the pupil of Guido, who also belongs to this school.
bibliographic_reference: Dunbar, Margaret Juliana (1853). Art and Nature under an Italian Sky.

name: As soon as we possibly could, our steps were directed to the Accademia…
fragment: As soon as we possibly could, our steps were directed to the Accademia delle Belle Arte : it is a noble collection, admirably arranged, consisting chiefly of the native school. The works of the various artists are placed in a great measure chronologically.
bibliographic_reference: Dunbar, Margaret Juliana (1853). Art and Nature under an Italian Sky.

name: Here is almost a single instance in which one could look at a painting…
fragment: Here is almost a single instance in which one could look at a painting, where the subject is physical suffering, without disgust — the Martyrdom of St. Agnes, by Domenichino. It is a large picture containing a vast number of figures, all admirable, yet in nothing distracting the eye from the principal one.
bibliographic_reference: Dunbar, Margaret Juliana (1853). Art and Nature under an Italian Sky.

name: To the treasures which more properly belong to Bologna, viz., the prod…
fragment: To the treasures which more properly belong to Bologna, viz., the productions of her own scholars, has been added a precious gem of Raphael's — the Santa Cecilia. I was instantly struck with this countenance, not only with its expressive beauty, but the extraordinary likeness it bears to one most dear to me.
bibliographic_reference: Dunbar, Margaret Juliana (1853). Art and Nature under an Italian Sky.

name: “The Massacre of the Innocents." In all respects it is the strongest c…
fragment: “The Massacre of the Innocents." In all respects it is the strongest contrast to the " Samson." Terror, agony, wild despair, are each and all here portrayed. And while, my eye passed from one form of anguish to another, I felt ready to shrink before the stern determination of those fierce and pitiless soldiers, as if in living contact with them. I hid my face in my hands after gazing on one who, by the might of her mother's love, has succeeded in shielding as yet her precious baby by her own form. Oh I that relentless wretch 1 can he — will he — take the little one even from those bleeding arms !
bibliographic_reference: Dunbar, Margaret Juliana (1853). Art and Nature under an Italian Sky.

name: Mr. Beckford calls Bologna " a city of puppy dogs and sausages," It wa…
fragment: Mr. Beckford calls Bologna " a city of puppy dogs and sausages," It was probably this remark that made us curious to experiment upon the latter. Accordingly, when the waiter brought in tea, we ordered a portion of the renowned condiment. Alas for unsophisticated palates! The smell alone was nearly enough — the first mouthful was more than enough ; and ere a second was even contemplated, we changed our plates, and sent the vile combination of raw meat and garlic in disgrace from the room!
bibliographic_reference: Dunbar, Margaret Juliana (1853). Art and Nature under an Italian Sky.

name: From Lojano to Pianoro, the descent is very abrupt, requiring addition…
fragment: From Lojano to Pianoro, the descent is very abrupt, requiring additional drags upon the wheels. The views here, from various points of the road, are exceedingly striking.
bibliographic_reference: Dunbar, Margaret Juliana (1853). Art and Nature under an Italian Sky.

name: Another masterpiece of this artist I find I have noted down, the Madon…
fragment: Another masterpiece of this artist I find I have noted down, the Madonna del Rosario — by some considered to surpass even the St. Jerome in the Vatican.
bibliographic_reference: Dunbar, Margaret Juliana (1853). Art and Nature under an Italian Sky.

name: I seldom think of these pictures unless accident recall them; whereas…
fragment: I seldom think of these pictures unless accident recall them; whereas some there are which visit me in the dreamy hour of half unconscious musing, and which suggest the mental filling up of a history by the single page which they unfold. " Abraham dismissing Hagar " — " The Sibyl " in the Borghese Palace, are instances of this; — and now I have two more to add to these, which I saw in the Gallery of Bologna. The first is "Samson having obtained the Victory over the Philistines," by Guido. [...] Very reluctantly did I turn away from the majestic painting; yet but a few paces from it, I was arrested by another, which called forth the same sort of intense feeling, “The Massacre of the Innocents."
bibliographic_reference: Dunbar, Margaret Juliana (1853). Art and Nature under an Italian Sky.

name: A brilliant moonlight evening tempted us out, wearied though we were.…
fragment: A brilliant moonlight evening tempted us out, wearied though we were. The deep shadows underneath the arches of the Colonnade contrasted with the strong light beyond, and we remarked how fitting a time and place it seemed for the scene of some tale of the lurking assassin, with his gleaming stiletto.
bibliographic_reference: Dunbar, Margaret Juliana (1853). Art and Nature under an Italian Sky.

name: This city, like Florence, offers a most agree able place of residence…
fragment: This city, like Florence, offers a most agree able place of residence to the stranger, being well built and clean, and having wide arcades in all the streets, as a protection from the sun; the environs are rich and picturesque.
bibliographic_reference: Carne, John (1834). Letters from Switzerland and Italy, During a Late Tour by the Author of "Letters from the East" & "Travel in the East".

name: The route to Bologna was in part wild and dreary. The country for a co…
fragment: The route to Bologna was in part wild and dreary. The country for a considerable distance around the city is so richly and variously cultivated, that it looks more like a garden than the territory of peasants.
bibliographic_reference: Carne, John (1834). Letters from Switzerland and Italy, During a Late Tour by the Author of "Letters from the East" & "Travel in the East".

name: The gallery of paintings near the university contains many of the fine…
fragment: The gallery of paintings near the university contains many of the finest works in Italy, consisting chiefly of those of the Caracci, Guido, and Domenichino. The martyrdom of a christian family by the latter is a noble subject; a young and delicate lady, of great beauty, and richly dressed, is the chief figure, kneeling, her eyes and hands lifted towards Heaven for fortitude to bear her through the trial.
bibliographic_reference: Carne, John (1834). Letters from Switzerland and Italy, During a Late Tour by the Author of "Letters from the East" & "Travel in the East".

name: The Samson of Guido is a noble picture; the figure is as large as life…
fragment: The Samson of Guido is a noble picture; the figure is as large as life, and the attitude beautiful and full of majesty. He is resting from the slaughter of the Philistines, and stands victorious amidst the havoc he has wrought; the right hand raised, holds the bone filled with water, which he is about to drink, and on which his look is fixed with intense eagerness. How refreshing to turn from the eternal martyrs and prelates to such a theme; they almost realise the complaint of the traveller who came to a strange isle, where the people were very handsome, but their faces were all alike
bibliographic_reference: Carne, John (1834). Letters from Switzerland and Italy, During a Late Tour by the Author of "Letters from the East" & "Travel in the East".

name: The most remarkable thing here is the uncommon beauty of the women; sc…
fragment: The most remarkable thing here is the uncommon beauty of the women; scarcely a plain face is to be seen: whether he looks on a company of women washing linen in the stream, or enters any of the shops, the traveller is alike struck with the loveliness of the features, and the symmetry of the forms. The eyes of the daughters of Bologna are large and dark, their complexions good, though with little colour, and their manners amiable and lively
bibliographic_reference: Carne, John (1834). Letters from Switzerland and Italy, During a Late Tour by the Author of "Letters from the East" & "Travel in the East".

name: The University of Bologna holds a righ rank among the literary institu…
fragment: The University of Bologna holds a righ rank among the literary institutions of Italy. Here the first dissection was performed in the fourteenth century, and galvanism was discovered in our own. Some of its present professors are men of considerable reputation; Orioli, professor of physics, and the celebrated Mezzofanti, of oriental languages.
bibliographic_reference: Carne, John (1834). Letters from Switzerland and Italy, During a Late Tour by the Author of "Letters from the East" & "Travel in the East".

name: Bologna can boast at various times of female professors. In the fourte…
fragment: Bologna can boast at various times of female professors. In the fourteenth century, Novella di Andrea used to supply her father's place in the chair of canon law, and, as she was young and handsome, she is said to have had a curtain before her, that the attention of the students might not be distracted. In the last century, Laura Bassi taught philosophy; and still more lately, the celebrated Clotilde Tambroni, Greek; and at the present moment there are two female professors, one of law and the other of surgery.
bibliographic_reference: Carne, John (1834). Letters from Switzerland and Italy, During a Late Tour by the Author of "Letters from the East" & "Travel in the East".

name: The library of the University contains, it is said, eighty thousand pr…
fragment: The library of the University contains, it is said, eighty thousand printed volumes, and four hundred MSS. There is also a botanical garden, and an agrarian garden, where a course of agriculture is given
bibliographic_reference: Carne, John (1834). Letters from Switzerland and Italy, During a Late Tour by the Author of "Letters from the East" & "Travel in the East".

name: The Instituto must, however, be noticed: among many curious helps to s…
fragment: The Instituto must, however, be noticed: among many curious helps to science, which its numerous rooms contain, we saw the fino collection of astronomical instruments purchased from the effects of Lord Cowper, and the admirable wax representations of anatomical subjects, particularly of the pails of the head.
bibliographic_reference: Gray, Robert (1791). Letters During the Course of a Tour Through Germany, Switzerland, and Italy in the years MDCCXCI and MDCCXCII.
place: Accademie - Accademia delle Scienze Istituto di Bologna

name: The university of Bologna still retains some of its ancient reputation…
fragment: The university of Bologna still retains some of its ancient reputation, as the chief school of civil jurisprudence cultivated in conjunction with the elegant parts of literature.
bibliographic_reference: Gray, Robert (1791). Letters During the Course of a Tour Through Germany, Switzerland, and Italy in the years MDCCXCI and MDCCXCII.

name: If the whole body were delineated with the fame accuracy as were the p…
fragment: If the whole body were delineated with the fame accuracy as were the parts which we saw, and were generally introduced, it might supersede the necessity of exhibiting dead bodies in anatomical schools, which are always obtained with difficulty, and viewed with horror or disgust.
bibliographic_reference: Gray, Robert (1791). Letters During the Course of a Tour Through Germany, Switzerland, and Italy in the years MDCCXCI and MDCCXCII.
place: Accademie - Accademia delle Scienze Istituto di Bologna

name: Public lectures are read at this university, by the professors, withou…
fragment: Public lectures are read at this university, by the professors, without any additional pay, so at least our conductor told us
bibliographic_reference: Gray, Robert (1791). Letters During the Course of a Tour Through Germany, Switzerland, and Italy in the years MDCCXCI and MDCCXCII.

name: This Torre d'Asinello, ascended by 447 steps of a foote rise, seems ex…
fragment: This Torre d'Asinello, ascended by 447 steps of a foote rise, seems exceedingly high, is very narrow, and the more conspicuous from another tower call'd Garisenda so artificially built of brick (which increases the wonder) that it seems ready to fall: 'tis not now so high as the other, but they say the upper part was formerly taken down for feare it should really fall and do mischief.
bibliographic_reference: Evelyn, John (1819). Memoirs.

name: Thence to St.Dominic's, where that saint's body lies richly inshrin'd.…
fragment: Thence to St.Dominic's, where that saint's body lies richly inshrin'd. The stalls, or seates of this goodly church have the historie of the Bible inlaied with severall woods very curiously don, the work of one Fr. Damiano di Bergomo and a frier of that order. Amongst other reliques they shew the two books of Esdras written with his own hand. Here lie buried Jac. Andreas and divers other learn'd persons. To the Church joynes the Convent, in ye quadrangle whereof are old cypresses, said to have been planted by their Saint.
bibliographic_reference: Evelyn, John (1819). Memoirs.
place: Di Culto - Basilica Di San Domenico
Di Culto - Convento di San Domenico

name: The rest of the afternoone was taken up in St. Michael in Bosco, built…
fragment: The rest of the afternoone was taken up in St. Michael in Bosco, built on a steepe hill on the edge of ye Citty, for its fabrick, pleasant shade and groves, cellars, dormitory, and prospects, one of the most delicious retirements I ever saw, art and nature contending which shall exceede; so as till now I never envied the life of a frier.
bibliographic_reference: Evelyn, John (1819). Memoirs.
place: Di Culto - Monastero San Michele in Bosco

name: This Citty is famous also for sausages; and here is sold greate quanti…
fragment: This Citty is famous also for sausages; and here is sold greate quantities of Parmegiano cheese, with Botargo, Caviare, &c. which makes some of their shops perfume ye streetes with no agreeable smell.
bibliographic_reference: Evelyn, John (1819). Memoirs.

name: In this Convent there are many excellent paintings of Guido Rheni, abo…
fragment: In this Convent there are many excellent paintings of Guido Rheni, above all, the little cloister of 8 faces painted by Carracci in fresco. The carvings in wood in the sacristy are admirable, as is the inlay'd work about ye Chapell, which even emulates the best paintings, the work is so delicate and tender.
bibliographic_reference: Evelyn, John (1819). Memoirs.
place: Di Culto - Monastero San Michele in Bosco

name: This towne belongs to the Pope, and is a famous University, situate in…
fragment: This towne belongs to the Pope, and is a famous University, situate in one of the richest spots of Europe for all sorts of provisions. 'Tis built like a ship, where of the Torre d'Asinello may go for the mainmast. The Citty is of no greate strength, having a trifling wall about it, in circuit neere 5 miles, and 2 in length.
bibliographic_reference: Evelyn, John (1819). Memoirs.

name: the whole towne is so cloyster'd that one may passe from house to hou…
fragment: the whole towne is so cloyster'd that one may passe from house to house through the streets without being expos'd either to raine or sun.
bibliographic_reference: Evelyn, John (1819). Memoirs.

name: Then we went to the Palace of the Legat, a faire brick building, as ar…
fragment: Then we went to the Palace of the Legat, a faire brick building, as are most of the houses and buildings for the whole towne, full of excellent carving and mouldings, so as nothing in stone seemes to be better finish'd or more ornamentall
bibliographic_reference: Evelyn, John (1819). Memoirs.

name: The Piazza before it is the most stately in Italy, St. Mark's at Venic…
fragment: The Piazza before it is the most stately in Italy, St. Mark's at Venice only excepted.
bibliographic_reference: Evelyn, John (1819). Memoirs.

name: I would faine have seene the Library of St. Saviour's, famous for ye n…
fragment: I would faine have seene the Library of St. Saviour's, famous for ye number of rare manuscripts, but could not, so we went to St. Francis's, a glorious pile and exceedingly adorn'd within.
bibliographic_reference: Evelyn, John (1819). Memoirs.
place: Di Culto - Basilica Di San Francesco

name: Indeede this Citty is full of rare pieces, especialy of Guido, Domenic…
fragment: Indeede this Citty is full of rare pieces, especialy of Guido, Domenico, and a virgin named Isabella Sirani, now living, who has painted many excellent pieces, and imitates Guido so well that many skilfull artists have been deceiv'd.
bibliographic_reference: Evelyn, John (1819). Memoirs.

name: This place has also been famous for lutes made by the old masters, Mol…
fragment: This place has also been famous for lutes made by the old masters, Mollen, Hans Frey, and Nicholas Sconvelt, which were of extraordinary price; the workmen were chiefly Germans.
bibliographic_reference: Evelyn, John (1819). Memoirs.

name: for two whole days, we literally travelled through an uninterrupted su…
fragment: for two whole days, we literally travelled through an uninterrupted succession of cornfields, vineyards and orchards, all in the highest state of cultivation, with the hedges neatly clipped into a kind of trellis-work, and the vines hanging in festoons from tree to tree, or clinging “with marriageable arms" round the branches of each regularly planted and friendly support.
bibliographic_reference: Hazlitt, William (1826). Notes of a Journey through France and Italy.

name: If its streets are less stately, its public buildings are more picture…
fragment: If its streets are less stately, its public buildings are more picturesque and varied; and its long arcades, its porticos and silent walks are a perpetual feast to the eye and the imagination
bibliographic_reference: Hazlitt, William (1826). Notes of a Journey through France and Italy.

name: Here is the Falling Tower, and the Neptune of John of Bologna, in the…
fragment: Here is the Falling Tower, and the Neptune of John of Bologna, in the great square
bibliographic_reference: Hazlitt, William (1826). Notes of a Journey through France and Italy.

name: Going along, we met Professor Mezzofanti, who is said to undestand thi…
fragment: Going along, we met Professor Mezzofanti, who is said to undestand thirty-eight languages, English among the rest.
bibliographic_reference: Hazlitt, William (1826). Notes of a Journey through France and Italy.

name: The college likewise called the Instituto pleased me, which is a found…
fragment: The college likewise called the Instituto pleased me, which is a foundation for the study of most arts and sciences. The sudden transition from a room full of architecture, to another where there are all sorts of models of fortification, and a third ornamented with things belonging to naval affairs, chemistry or other sciences, is pleasing. Besides there is a good museum of curiosities, and some paintings by no means despicable
bibliographic_reference: Hervey, C. (1785). Letters from Portugal, Spain, Italy and Germany in the years 1759, 1760, and 1761.
place: Accademie - Accademia delle Scienze Istituto di Bologna

name: The city is handsome, tho' the streets are in some places narrow, and…
fragment: The city is handsome, tho' the streets are in some places narrow, and through most of them on each side runs a colonnade formed like the piazzas in Covent-garden, that a foot passenger may walk about the town in rainy weather with very little wet.
bibliographic_reference: Hervey, C. (1785). Letters from Portugal, Spain, Italy and Germany in the years 1759, 1760, and 1761.

name: All that seemed to me to be wanting were the students, but I suppose t…
fragment: All that seemed to me to be wanting were the students, but I suppose there are times when they appear, however I saw nobody.
bibliographic_reference: Hervey, C. (1785). Letters from Portugal, Spain, Italy and Germany in the years 1759, 1760, and 1761.

name: This town tho' under the pope, has much the air of a republic, and ind…
fragment: This town tho' under the pope, has much the air of a republic, and indeed, upon its surrender to the holy see, many of its privileges were preserved.
bibliographic_reference: Hervey, C. (1785). Letters from Portugal, Spain, Italy and Germany in the years 1759, 1760, and 1761.

name: Our third day's journey was to Bologna, which we reached in six hours.…
fragment: Our third day's journey was to Bologna, which we reached in six hours. The road hither being hilly, but good, the former part of the country bold and romantic, then latter part rich and beautiful.
bibliographic_reference: Starke, Mariana (1802). Travels in Italy, between the years 1792 and 1798.

name: One of our Party, a young Lady afflicted with weak lungs, was made ala…
fragment: One of our Party, a young Lady afflicted with weak lungs, was made alarmingly ill by crossing the Apennine to Bologna, (it being a journey of two days over these mountains, which are quite as cold as the Alps;)
bibliographic_reference: Starke, Mariana (1802). Travels in Italy, between the years 1792 and 1798.

name: The City of Bologna is strikingly magnificent; its environs are charmi…
fragment: The City of Bologna is strikingly magnificent; its environs are charming, and, exclusive of the coats of arms being either defaced or taken down from the outsides of palaces and public buildings, this country exhibits no marks of the ravages of war. The most interesting objects to Travellers are — the Sampieri Palace, and the Neptune of Giovanni di Bologna. The former contains a most valuable gallery of pictures
bibliographic_reference: Starke, Mariana (1802). Travels in Italy, between the years 1792 and 1798.

name: The Neptune of Giovanni di Bologna is one of our very finest pieces of…
fragment: The Neptune of Giovanni di Bologna is one of our very finest pieces of modern sculpture!
bibliographic_reference: Starke, Mariana (1802). Travels in Italy, between the years 1792 and 1798.

name: This City contains, in its Churches and Palaces, an immense number of…
fragment: This City contains, in its Churches and Palaces, an immense number of excellent paintings by the Caracci Family, their Scholars, &c. not mentioned above. In short, so many fine things remain, that those taken away by the French arc scarcely missed.
bibliographic_reference: Starke, Mariana (1802). Travels in Italy, between the years 1792 and 1798.

name: The church bears the name of the Madonna di San Luca, from the famous…
fragment: The church bears the name of the Madonna di San Luca, from the famous portrait of the Virgin, painted by the hand of the Evangelist, and which it is the boast and glory of the Bolognese to possess.
bibliographic_reference: Owen, John (1796). Travels Into Different Parts of Europe, In the Years 1791 and 1792. With Familiar Remarks on Places, Men and Manners.
artwork: Dipinto - Effigie Beata Vergine col Bambino

name: Bologna is a town, the remembrance of whose beauties will not readily…
fragment: Bologna is a town, the remembrance of whose beauties will not readily be effaced from my mind
bibliographic_reference: Owen, John (1796). Travels Into Different Parts of Europe, In the Years 1791 and 1792. With Familiar Remarks on Places, Men and Manners.

name: I had heard so much of the celebrity of St. Luke at Bologna, that I im…
fragment: I had heard so much of the celebrity of St. Luke at Bologna, that I immediately requested to be conducted thither. The path to this church is a continual ascent; but pilgrims of all ages, and labouring under whatever infirmities, seemed to tread it without reluctance or fatigue.
bibliographic_reference: Owen, John (1796). Travels Into Different Parts of Europe, In the Years 1791 and 1792. With Familiar Remarks on Places, Men and Manners.
place: Di Culto - Santuario Di San Luca

name: This portico has considerable beauty, and still more convenience, as i…
fragment: This portico has considerable beauty, and still more convenience, as it affords at once the means of shelter and of rest. It was raised by voluntary contribution; six hundred and forty-eight arcades compose the whole range; all of which were built at different periods by the zealous devotion of private persons, or different corporations
bibliographic_reference: Owen, John (1796). Travels Into Different Parts of Europe, In the Years 1791 and 1792. With Familiar Remarks on Places, Men and Manners.

name: The church is an elegant building, and bears on its walls some tablets…
fragment: The church is an elegant building, and bears on its walls some tablets, commemorative of miracles performed by this marvellous picture. This inestimable treasure is provokingly covered with a cafe, ornamented with jewels, and different offerings of devotion; so that I could only judge of St. Luke's pencil by its miraculous effects.
bibliographic_reference: Owen, John (1796). Travels Into Different Parts of Europe, In the Years 1791 and 1792. With Familiar Remarks on Places, Men and Manners.
place: Di Culto - Santuario Di San Luca
artwork: Dipinto - Effigie Beata Vergine col Bambino

name: when religion is addressed to the senses rather than the understanding…
fragment: when religion is addressed to the senses rather than the understanding, there is nothing too ridiculous to become the object of adoration; and, for my own part, I can discern in the rationality of this species of devotion no difference between the tomb of Mahomet and the cross of Calvary —the image of Diana that fell down from heaven, and the portrait of the Virgin painted by Saint Luke.
bibliographic_reference: Owen, John (1796). Travels Into Different Parts of Europe, In the Years 1791 and 1792. With Familiar Remarks on Places, Men and Manners.
place: Di Culto - Santuario Di San Luca
artwork: Dipinto - Effigie Beata Vergine col Bambino

name: A string of beads, which I purchased to escape the suspicion of heresy…
fragment: A string of beads, which I purchased to escape the suspicion of heresy, entitled me to a little tract, written by the Abbé Calindri, from which I learned the very high value set upon this precious deposit, the solemnity with which it is venerated at Bologna, and the innumerable benefits which have been derived by this city from its residence among them.
bibliographic_reference: Owen, John (1796). Travels Into Different Parts of Europe, In the Years 1791 and 1792. With Familiar Remarks on Places, Men and Manners.
artwork: Dipinto - Effigie Beata Vergine col Bambino

name: This ceremony has also been performed in cafes of public emergency, a…
fragment: This ceremony has also been performed in cafes of public emergency, as was the cafe in 1779, on account of repeated earthquakes. The consequence was, that though these shocks were so violent, and so frequent as to agitate the country for three years, the city of Bologna sustained no sensible mischiefs from this scourge, which, during its continuance, committed such ravages in the circumjacent cities
bibliographic_reference: Owen, John (1796). Travels Into Different Parts of Europe, In the Years 1791 and 1792. With Familiar Remarks on Places, Men and Manners.

name: The first object that strikes a traveller on entering the town, is the…
fragment: The first object that strikes a traveller on entering the town, is the square tower of Asinelli, 307 French feet, or about 110 yards in height, built of brick, in the year 1109; very slender, and of an equal diameter all the way up. It has inclined a few inches from the perpendicular by time. The brick work must have been considerably different from the shameful mud walls so plentifully erecting daily about London.
bibliographic_reference: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.

name: an excellent painting of the Transfiguration, by Ludovico Carracci, on…
fragment: an excellent painting of the Transfiguration, by Ludovico Carracci, one of the best of his works that I have seen. There is great nobleness in the design, and the drawing and colouring are good, though the latter is a little gray.
bibliographic_reference: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.

name: At the Servi di Maria, St. Andrew adoring his cross is an excellent pe…
fragment: At the Servi di Maria, St. Andrew adoring his cross is an excellent performance of Al bano's, and a Noli me tangere of the same artist deserves attention.
bibliographic_reference: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.

name: The principal objects of a stranger's curiosity in this town are the n…
fragment: The principal objects of a stranger's curiosity in this town are the numerous pictures, of which all the palaces and churches are full. Here the productions of the Bolognese school, the works of the Carraccis, of Guido Rheni, Domenichino, Albano, &c. may be seen in the greatest abundance and perfection. We spent four days in contemplating them.
bibliographic_reference: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.

name: The day was unfavourable for a view, but we could well distinguish Imo…
fragment: The day was unfavourable for a view, but we could well distinguish Imola, Ferrara, and Modena ; as well as the hills about Verona, Mount Baldus, &c. seeming to rise abruptly from the dead flat which extends on three sides of Bologna. On the south are some very pleasant hills stuck with villas.
bibliographic_reference: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.

name: The tower of Garissendi, close to the above mentioned, is not half so…
fragment: The tower of Garissendi, close to the above mentioned, is not half so high ; but said to have been purposely built leaning eight feet out of the perpendicular. This point however is doubtful, and the guide book of the place fays the foundations have given away ; which is most probable
bibliographic_reference: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.

name: Bologna possesses a very famous public academy, called the Palazzo del…
fragment: Bologna possesses a very famous public academy, called the Palazzo dell' Instituto, where all the sciences are taught gratis. Here is an ample Museum, Library, and apparatus for Natural Philosophy.
bibliographic_reference: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.
place: Accademie - Accademia delle Scienze Istituto di Bologna

name: The plaster models of gravid uteri, with almost all possible situation…
fragment: The plaster models of gravid uteri, with almost all possible situations and cases done from nature, are very good, though less beautiful than the anatomical models at Florence.
bibliographic_reference: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.

name: The collection of corals is generally good, especially Isis nobilis, r…
fragment: The collection of corals is generally good, especially Isis nobilis, red coral, of a variety of shades, from deep scarlet to a blush colour and pure white. One specimen has even red and white in the same piece, as mentioned by Tournefort. There are some fine Spongiœ, and some tolerable Amphibia. A very large very large Testudo coriacea, taken by accident near Civita Vecchia.
bibliographic_reference: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.

name: The minerals are not capital ; but there are some fine real Sicilian j…
fragment: The minerals are not capital ; but there are some fine real Sicilian jaspers, and a collection, presented by the reigning empress of Russia, of the stones of Siberia.
bibliographic_reference: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.

name: In one of the great halls is an admirable whole-length portrait, in mo…
fragment: In one of the great halls is an admirable whole-length portrait, in mosaic, of Benedict XIV. executed at Rome. In another room are some curious old pictures, done by the earliest painters of the Bolognese school, some of them of considerable merit. This establishment is entirely owing to Count Marfigli
bibliographic_reference: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.

name: S. Salvatore, whose Corinthian architecture is very majestic, has many…
fragment: S. Salvatore, whose Corinthian architecture is very majestic, has many tomb stones and holy-water batons of an orange- coloured speckled marble, called rosso di Verona, which I first saw at Loretto.
bibliographic_reference: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.
place: Di Culto - Chiesa di San Salvatore

name: St. John before Zaccharias, with other saints, by Benvenuto Garofalo,…
fragment: St. John before Zaccharias, with other saints, by Benvenuto Garofalo, is excellent ; but St. John kneels very badly ; he could not possibly support himself as he is represented.
bibliographic_reference: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.
place: Di Culto - Chiesa di San Salvatore
artwork: Dipinto - San Giovanni Battista si congeda dal padre Zaccaria

name: There are some small pictures of saints, by Giotto, curious for their…
fragment: There are some small pictures of saints, by Giotto, curious for their antiquity ; and in the sacristy a pretty good St. Sebastian of Guido Rheni ; and David, with Goliath's head at his feet, by Giovanni Antonio Burrini, in which there is great force of light and shade, like Spagnuoletto's works.
bibliographic_reference: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.
place: Di Culto - Chiesa di San Salvatore
artwork: Dipinto - David con la testa di Golia

name: At St. Paulo, on the high-altar, under a half dome supported by column…
fragment: At St. Paulo, on the high-altar, under a half dome supported by columns, are the admirable statues of St. Paul and his executioner, by Algardi. Nothing can be finer than the meek resignation of the saint, who is kneeling in expectation of the fatal stroke, with his face turned from the executioner.
bibliographic_reference: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.
place: Di Culto - Basilica di San Paolo Maggiore

name: St. Dominic's is a long but not inelegant church, in which the most re…
fragment: St. Dominic's is a long but not inelegant church, in which the most remarkable thing is the shrine of that famous faint, whose apt emblem, as I have already remarked, was a dog with a firebrand in his mouth.
bibliographic_reference: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.
place: Di Culto - Basilica Di San Domenico

name: There is a chink in the back of the sarcophagus, where devout persons…
fragment: There is a chink in the back of the sarcophagus, where devout persons have fancied they smelt celestial fragrance. We unfortunately had not faith enough to perceive it ; but I could not help thinking how feelingly we should have been converted, if " Dominic the blacksmith " had thrust out " his tongs red hot " and taken us by the nose.
bibliographic_reference: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.
place: Di Culto - Basilica Di San Domenico

name: The shrine is gothic, of white marble, extremely rich in sculpture, an…
fragment: The shrine is gothic, of white marble, extremely rich in sculpture, and terminating upwards in a pyramidal form. On the sarcophagus are an immense number of figures in alto-relievo, of good execution, by an unknown artist. At each extremity of the adjoining altar is a small kneeling angel of white marble.
bibliographic_reference: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.
place: Di Culto - Basilica Di San Domenico

name: The celebrated St. Cecilia, with St. Paul, Mary Magdalen, and other co…
fragment: The celebrated St. Cecilia, with St. Paul, Mary Magdalen, and other company, by Raphael ; which has been engraved and often copied. I was a little disappointed in the principal figure, as to its personal beauty and grace ; the Magdalen pleased me much better.
bibliographic_reference: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.

name: The Virgin of the Rosary, by Domenichino ; a confused composition with…
fragment: The Virgin of the Rosary, by Domenichino ; a confused composition with a great number of figures, of which I cannot understand the design ; but its parts are admirable.
bibliographic_reference: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.

name: Giovanni in Monte is adorned with many pictures, the three principal o…
fragment: Giovanni in Monte is adorned with many pictures, the three principal of which are, 1st, St. Francis adoring the crucifix, by Guercino; the author of which I should never have guessed. The crucifix is placed on the ground in the forepart, so that the saint's eyes are directed at once to it, and to the crucifix on the altar below. The colouring of this picture is remarkably still ; its expression good.
bibliographic_reference: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.
place: Di Culto - Chiesa di San Giovanni in Monte

name: St. Petronio is a vast old gothic structure, much more resembling a ca…
fragment: St. Petronio is a vast old gothic structure, much more resembling a cathedral, though the front is of brick, and unfinished. Most of the buildings in this city are of brick, a great disadvantage to their beauty. In this church is a famous meridian line, made in 1656, and repaired in 1776.
bibliographic_reference: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.
place: Di Culto - Basilica Di San Petronio

name: The cathedral, or Duomo, is a large majestic building internally, of t…
fragment: The cathedral, or Duomo, is a large majestic building internally, of the Corinthian order, but with several faults. The arch over the entrance of the tribune is too narrow, and the semicircular niche at the extremity too low. The most remarkable picture here, St. Peter consecrating St. Apollinarius a bishop, by Gratiani, has great merit in the design.
bibliographic_reference: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.

name: St. George and the Dragon, by Ludovico Carracci, did not please me muc…
fragment: St. George and the Dragon, by Ludovico Carracci, did not please me much; neither did the picture by Guercino, of St. Felix putting the monastic habit on St. William. It is confused, and the colouring seems to have suffered.
bibliographic_reference: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.
artwork: Dipinto - San Giorgio e il drago

name: The church of St. Francis, not far distant, is a venerable pile ; in w…
fragment: The church of St. Francis, not far distant, is a venerable pile ; in which nothing struck me so much as the fine gothic altar-piece of white marble, consisting of a kind of screen, on which are ranged several statues of saints in two rows.
bibliographic_reference: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.
place: Di Culto - Basilica Di San Francesco

name: St. Catherine, or Corpus Domini, is a taw dry church ; but the front o…
fragment: St. Catherine, or Corpus Domini, is a taw dry church ; but the front of an altar, in the first chapel on the right hand, consists of perhaps the finest piece of verde antico, for the clearness and great size of its spots, that Italy can boast.
bibliographic_reference: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.
place: Di Culto - Chiesa Del Corpus Domini

name: Through a silver grate, over an altar, we had a view of the body of St…
fragment: Through a silver grate, over an altar, we had a view of the body of St. Catherine Vigri, the foundress; which is preserved entire by a miracle, as they do the Almighty the honour of supposing. She is sitting, richly dressed, in a chair, with candles burning about her. The face, hands, and feet are visible, and of a chocolate colour. On her cheek is a whitish mark, said to have been occasioned by Jesus Christ appearing to her in a dream and giving her a kiss
bibliographic_reference: Smith, Sir James Edward (1787). A Sketch of a Tour on the Continent, In the Years 1786 and 1787.
place: Di Culto - Chiesa Del Corpus Domini

name: These Seven Churches, and especially the Templar’s Church called House…
fragment: These Seven Churches, and especially the Templar’s Church called House of Pilate, are such a mise-en-scene as Wagner aimed at creating in his Parsifal. [...] It is, this House of Pilate, a place of indescribable mystery and awe [...]. It is a place whose appropriate sounds would not be plain-chants even, however archaic, but mutterings and wailings and solitary footfalls; a building which has the shuddering nightmare quality of the moments before a wintry dawn.
bibliographic_reference: Lee, Vernon (1922). "Dark, Many-Towered Bologna" in The North American Review.
place: Di Culto - Basilica Di Santo Stefano

name: Again, at evening in those Seven Churches, their very names, Atrio di…
fragment: Again, at evening in those Seven Churches, their very names, Atrio di Pilato or San Sepolcro, wonderfu
bibliographic_reference: Lee, Vernon (1922). "Dark, Many-Towered Bologna" in The North American Review.

name: Bologna seen between trains during a summer journey had become one of…
fragment: Bologna seen between trains during a summer journey had become one of those places which exist only in childhood where, in virtue of some one thing acquiring a supernatural value, all the most ordinary circumstances of life come to partake of its magic
bibliographic_reference: Lee, Vernon (1922). "Dark, Many-Towered Bologna" in The North American Review.

name: At Bologna the wonder-working objects (like the ring you turn or the l…
fragment: At Bologna the wonder-working objects (like the ring you turn or the lamp you rub in fairy tales) were those gaunt rooms of the Music School whence issued for the earthly ear piano scales, fiddle exercises and vocal arpeggi of doubtful accuracy; but which, the walls being hung with the portraits of seventeenth and eighteenth century musicians, were filled for the ear of my childish fancy with their unheard music, or at least with their music’s charm.
bibliographic_reference: Lee, Vernon (1922). "Dark, Many-Towered Bologna" in The North American Review.

name: They have restored churches and palaces in Bologna, Rubbiani and sundr…
fragment: They have restored churches and palaces in Bologna, Rubbiani and sundry other of my archaeological acquaintances; and rebuilt or disengaged the Ghibelline battlements, like wild tulip petals, of the House of King Enzo, son of Barbarossa.
bibliographic_reference: Lee, Vernon (1922). "Dark, Many-Towered Bologna" in The North American Review.

name: But at the base of the two leaning towers there no longer hang those g…
fragment: But at the base of the two leaning towers there no longer hang those great basins and pudding-moulds and ewers and platters and pitchers which were more resplendent in their delicate copper rosiness and brass yellow, and in a way more mediaeval almost, than any knight’s armor in the town museum.
bibliographic_reference: Lee, Vernon (1922). "Dark, Many-Towered Bologna" in The North American Review.

name: One of my haunts at Bologna was the Seven Churches round San Stefano.…
fragment: One of my haunts at Bologna was the Seven Churches round San Stefano. Seven they are called, though they seem far more numerous; a maze of low tin-roofed basilicas, chapels, crypts and shrines, cloisters also, and damp monastic yards under belfries and mysterious corridors, with graves and tabernacles tucked away in them; barracco Gesù Mortos shelved where you expect only broken chairs and derelict besoms, and the Three Kings, huge black Gothic chessmen, frightening you as you come suddenly up against them, with their goggle stare.
bibliographic_reference: Lee, Vernon (1922). "Dark, Many-Towered Bologna" in The North American Review.
place: Di Culto - Basilica Di Santo Stefano

name: There are not many such places as these Seven Churches even in Italy.
fragment: There are not many such places as these Seven Churches even in Italy.
bibliographic_reference: Lee, Vernon (1922). "Dark, Many-Towered Bologna" in The North American Review.
place: Di Culto - Basilica Di Santo Stefano

name: Churches like these Seven Churches of Bologna (and probably whatever t…
fragment: Churches like these Seven Churches of Bologna (and probably whatever temples the subterranean cults of ancient times possessed) seem like the lairs, the hidden resting-places, where mankind has cowered in silence and darkness with its broken limbs and sores and fever visions, resting and healing itself between the real miseries of this world and the imagined terrors of the next.
bibliographic_reference: Lee, Vernon (1922). "Dark, Many-Towered Bologna" in The North American Review.
place: Di Culto - Basilica Di Santo Stefano

name: How one does enjoy those fifteenth century Bolognese painters, mediocr…
fragment: How one does enjoy those fifteenth century Bolognese painters, mediocre to a man, after the over-gifted, over-strenuous Tuscans!
bibliographic_reference: Lee, Vernon (1922). "Dark, Many-Towered Bologna" in The North American Review.

name: When I had, as I thought, done with all this hive of hidden sanctuarie…
fragment: When I had, as I thought, done with all this hive of hidden sanctuaries, I came, turning a corner, to yet another little black chapel. And in it an old beldame insisted on unlocking the “Sacred House of Loreto,” as she called it, and telling me its unintelligible story. It seemed a narrow space behind an altar, where she set down a taper in a niche and, turning a handle and rolling back a shutter, displayed a black Madonna cocooned, in brocade, her star-crowned head barely emerging in puce and tinsel farthingale.
bibliographic_reference: Lee, Vernon (1922). "Dark, Many-Towered Bologna" in The North American Review.
place: Di Culto - Basilica Di Santo Stefano
Di Culto - Santuario Madonna di Loreto in Santo Stefano

name: The whole place was full of It: It, a vague terror and sorrow. But wha…
fragment: The whole place was full of It: It, a vague terror and sorrow. But what frightened me was none of all this, but just a human being, a man, perhaps a tourist, standing still in the dusk before the altar. The sight of him almost made my heart stop. That is what much of religion must have been for primeval man; and this little Templar’s church (or whatever in Italy takes the place of such) seems to be oozing with the mysteries of times long before Christianity, or even Paganism
bibliographic_reference: Lee, Vernon (1922). "Dark, Many-Towered Bologna" in The North American Review.
place: Di Culto - Basilica Di Santo Stefano

name: And against the pure washed sky I noticed for the first time that the…
fragment: And against the pure washed sky I noticed for the first time that the two leaning towers, which one thinks of as frowning dark, are really of an unsubstantial rose-color, weathered lilac, a color like that of the leafless woods on the Apennines above Bologna, bare just now, but already quickening under their delicate bark.
bibliographic_reference: Lee, Vernon (1922). "Dark, Many-Towered Bologna" in The North American Review.

name: I sat for a long while, waiting for the rain to stop, in San Giovanni…
fragment: I sat for a long while, waiting for the rain to stop, in San Giovanni in Monte, where Raphael’s St. Cecilia still hung when Dr. Burney visited Bologna in 1770. This church also was dark; but the round windows with Cossa’s fine John on Patmos was like a set out of jewels, colored, luminous, blazing.
bibliographic_reference: Lee, Vernon (1922). "Dark, Many-Towered Bologna" in The North American Review.
place: Di Culto - Chiesa di San Giovanni in Monte

name: As I was returning from my last regretful look round Bologna, there su…
fragment: As I was returning from my last regretful look round Bologna, there suddenly came, from the beautiful tulip-shaped belfry of San Pietro, a volley of bells, and (the most unexpected occurrence in Italy) actually chimes. Their sound seemed to add to my old, or rather my childish, love of Bologna my more recent love of Oxford; the emotion special to that aristocratic swept and garnished English Past enhancing the emotion inspired by this Lombard city, so venerable but still so nobly alive.
bibliographic_reference: Lee, Vernon (1922). "Dark, Many-Towered Bologna" in The North American Review.
place: Di Culto - Cattedrale di San Pietro

name: And in the little cloister with damp-green pavement in the shadow of t…
fragment: And in the little cloister with damp-green pavement in the shadow of the high walls and the belfry, you come upon a column with Peter’s Cock; no barn-door fowl, but a sort of bird-divinity, like the winged sphinxes and sirens which the ancients set on pillars at Delphi and elsewhere.
bibliographic_reference: Lee, Vernon (1922). "Dark, Many-Towered Bologna" in The North American Review.
place: Di Culto - Basilica Di Santo Stefano

name: The City itself lies much upon a Flat, but has on one side of it sever…
fragment: The City itself lies much upon a Flat, but has on one side of it several considerable Eminences; as that on which the noble Convento S. Michael in Bosco stands, that of the Capuchins, and others: From each of these we have a very fine view
bibliographic_reference: Wright, Esq. Edward (1764). Some Observations Made in Travelling: Through France, Italy, &c. in the Years 1720, 1721, and 1722.
place: Di Culto - Monastero San Michele in Bosco

name: All the principal Streets of the City, and many of the lesser ones, ha…
fragment: All the principal Streets of the City, and many of the lesser ones, have on each side a handsome Portico, after the Manner of that in Covent-Garden. Some Portico's are of one Order of Pillars ,some of another; some oddly fancied, of no regular Order
bibliographic_reference: Wright, Esq. Edward (1764). Some Observations Made in Travelling: Through France, Italy, &c. in the Years 1720, 1721, and 1722.

name: The Palazzo Ranuzzi is particularly famous for a very large and fine d…
fragment: The Palazzo Ranuzzi is particularly famous for a very large and fine double Staircase, and a noble Hall: The later is quite new, and but just finish'd when we were there,1721.
bibliographic_reference: Wright, Esq. Edward (1764). Some Observations Made in Travelling: Through France, Italy, &c. in the Years 1720, 1721, and 1722.

name: The Palazzo Caprara is one of the most magnificent for Architecture. I…
fragment: The Palazzo Caprara is one of the most magnificent for Architecture. It is built round a Court, of which a large Staircase with a double Ascent, takes up one side: A Gallery runs along the opposite side, furnilh'd with Spoils taken from the Turks, by a General of this Family.
bibliographic_reference: Wright, Esq. Edward (1764). Some Observations Made in Travelling: Through France, Italy, &c. in the Years 1720, 1721, and 1722.

name: On the Outside of the Palazzo Bolognini we saw some very fine Heads in…
fragment: On the Outside of the Palazzo Bolognini we saw some very fine Heads in Sculpture, much resembling the Antique; by Alphonso di Ferrara, and Giovanni Tedescho, as Signor Mazza [lately mention'd ]said ; but Count Bolognini himself told me they were all by Alphonso.
bibliographic_reference: Wright, Esq. Edward (1764). Some Observations Made in Travelling: Through France, Italy, &c. in the Years 1720, 1721, and 1722.

name: The Grounds about it are very rich, not only in the vast abundance of…
fragment: The Grounds about it are very rich, not only in the vast abundance of Vines, Olives, Chesnuts, and other Fruits, but likewise in Corn, and good Pasturage, which fills the Markets with great Plenty. The Beef they have there, is (I think) the finest I ever tasted.
bibliographic_reference: Wright, Esq. Edward (1764). Some Observations Made in Travelling: Through France, Italy, &c. in the Years 1720, 1721, and 1722.

name: The Entrance into the Palaces (of which there is a great Number in thi…
fragment: The Entrance into the Palaces (of which there is a great Number in this City) is generally very pleasant: You see at once from the Street into the Gardens quite through the whole House, which is often built round a Court
bibliographic_reference: Wright, Esq. Edward (1764). Some Observations Made in Travelling: Through France, Italy, &c. in the Years 1720, 1721, and 1722.

name: The Paintings in the Palaces, but more especially in the Churches, ar…
fragment: The Paintings in the Palaces, but more especially in the Churches, are vastly numerous, and many of them exceeding fine, by the best Masters of the Lombard-School, which the Virtuosi of the Place are so hardy as to prefer not only to the Venetian, but even to the Roman itself
bibliographic_reference: Wright, Esq. Edward (1764). Some Observations Made in Travelling: Through France, Italy, &c. in the Years 1720, 1721, and 1722.

name: no one Family ever sent out so many great Disciples as that of the Car…
fragment: no one Family ever sent out so many great Disciples as that of the Caracci did, of whole excellent Works there is great plenty
bibliographic_reference: Wright, Esq. Edward (1764). Some Observations Made in Travelling: Through France, Italy, &c. in the Years 1720, 1721, and 1722.

name: These Fathers have a circular Cloyster, which was admirably painted by…
fragment: These Fathers have a circular Cloyster, which was admirably painted by Guido, Ludovico Caracci, and others; but has been miserably abus'd: They have a Gallery a hundred and eighty four Paces long.
bibliographic_reference: Wright, Esq. Edward (1764). Some Observations Made in Travelling: Through France, Italy, &c. in the Years 1720, 1721, and 1722.
place: Di Culto - Monastero San Michele in Bosco Chiostro
Di Culto - Monastero San Michele in Bosco Corridoio

name: The Certosa [Carthusians] stands in a fine Air, and pleasant Situation…
fragment: The Certosa [Carthusians] stands in a fine Air, and pleasant Situation, in the midst of Vineyards. They have several Courts with Cloysters, one as large as the great Court of Trinity College in Cambridge.
bibliographic_reference: Wright, Esq. Edward (1764). Some Observations Made in Travelling: Through France, Italy, &c. in the Years 1720, 1721, and 1722.

name: Each Father has to his proper Cell a pretty Garden, in which some of t…
fragment: Each Father has to his proper Cell a pretty Garden, in which some of them are very curious, having many exotick Plants, &c. One of them had Fish in his Cistern, which did cat Lettuce, and other Herbs out of our Hands. This Father had tried some Experiments in Grafting; as of a Vine on a Fig-Tree, Jasmin on an Orange, which had taken, and grew.
bibliographic_reference: Wright, Esq. Edward (1764). Some Observations Made in Travelling: Through France, Italy, &c. in the Years 1720, 1721, and 1722.

name: I think, indeed, one can hardly have a just Idea of the Bolognese Mast…
fragment: I think, indeed, one can hardly have a just Idea of the Bolognese Masters, such as the Caracci's , Guido, &c. Who has not seen their Performances in the Churches here; the great Freedom of Hand, and the superior Spirit in those grand Designs strikes much more than what we generally see in their smaller Pieces does.
bibliographic_reference: Wright, Esq. Edward (1764). Some Observations Made in Travelling: Through France, Italy, &c. in the Years 1720, 1721, and 1722.

name: In the Church of Corpus Domini they shew'd us the Body of liana Cathar…
fragment: In the Church of Corpus Domini they shew'd us the Body of liana Catharina Vigri, clothed in Cloth of Silver: In her right Hand she holds a Silver Cross, her left rests on a Book which lies on her Knee: She sits under a Canopy, the Curtains of which are held back by Angels, gilt over: Other Angels of the fame forth old Wax Tapers on each side.
bibliographic_reference: Wright, Esq. Edward (1764). Some Observations Made in Travelling: Through France, Italy, &c. in the Years 1720, 1721, and 1722.
place: Di Culto - Chiesa Del Corpus Domini

name: This Lady, according to their Account, has been dead above two hundred…
fragment: This Lady, according to their Account, has been dead above two hundred and fifty Years, yet her Nails grow, and are pared once a Year, and her Body wash'd, the Flesh of which they tell you is as soft as when alive: — That is to be taken upon their Words, for you see her only thro*a Grate.
bibliographic_reference: Wright, Esq. Edward (1764). Some Observations Made in Travelling: Through France, Italy, &c. in the Years 1720, 1721, and 1722.
place: Di Culto - Chiesa Del Corpus Domini

name: There are several painted upon Canvass in Guazzo [Water Colour,] by Fr…
